subject: RE: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods
msgSnippet: Hello Erik, In fact, you are saying that we should leave the fields accessible until the tests scream that they would prefer a getter/setter ? I do understand
messageBody:
Hello Erik,

In fact, you are saying that we should leave the fields accessible until the
tests scream that they would prefer a getter/setter ?

I do understand that the public (or protected) field is much simpler to test.
But that goes against everything I read in OOA/D/P books lately :)

Thanks,
Francois

--- Erik Husby <ehusby@...> a écrit : > I've been following this
thread with some amusement that someone hasn't said
> the obvious.
>
> If you don't know how to test the method then you don't understand the
> method.
>
> For instance, if I know I am going to have a setter that simple sets a
> variable and the
> getter that returns it, then the method mentioned before of:
>
> o.setThing( aThing );
> assertEquals( aThing, o.getThing());
>
> Works real well.
>
> But If you have a more complex set/get combination such as a getter that
> returns a clone
> of the variable then you would want something like:
>
> Point p = new Point(99,99);
> o.setPoint( p );
> assert( "Better not be same point object", p != o.getPoint());
> assertEquals("But better have same x,y", p, o.getPoint());
>
>
> As J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger said, "do not test what cannot possibly break."
> so you don't
> really need to test the simple set/get combination. But by the same token,
> make sure
> that you really need the simple set/get combination. Don't add them simply
> because you
> think you might need them someday. Add them because a test you are writing
> shows a need
> for them.
